sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,Songs from The Recruit, in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser (Charleston, February 19, 1796).

p.emph: The following Songs are in the Musical Interlude of the Recruit, written by Mr. Turnbull, of the Church-street Theatre, and performed for his Benefit on Saturday Evening last.

head.title: Song I.11 First published as "Song III" in Poetical Essays, (1788), pp. 216-217 ; reprinted in Poems (1794), pp. 38-39, as the first song in Turnbull’s comedy The Recruit, first performed at the Dumfries Theater, January 1794; and again with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

note.a: Tune. The mucking o’ Geordie’s byre.

div.note: 2 The air Turnbull used, “The Muckin’ o’ Geordie’s Byre,” had appeared in Orpheus Caledonius (1733), no. 33; Caledonian Pocket Companion, II (1745), p. 35; and (with earlier words) in Johnson, Scots Musical Museum, I (1787), no. 96; it was also used later by Burns for his song “Adown winding Nith I did wander” (Kinsley II:701), published in Thomson, Select Collection of Original Scotish Airs, II: set 3 (1799), song 66. The Recruit was first performed for Turnbull’s benefit performance in Dumfries in January, 1794. It was staged at the City Theatre, Church Street, Charleston, again for Turnbull’s benefit night, on March 11, 1796, and again at the Charleston Theatre, Broad Street, Charleston, on May 30, 1807.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Ye lads that are plaguet wi’ lasses,
Had need to be tenty33 adj. attentive. and slie,
Or soon ye’ll be guidet like asses,
Gif ye be as silly as me.
I courtet a lassie for siller,44 n. silver.
And she was right saucy and sprie;
But ’gin I was buckl’d until her,
The fient a scrap siller had she.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: But kent ye the way how I gat her,
Ye’d say it was cunning o’ me;
The chiels a’ gaed wood to be at her,
Sae cadgie55 adj. cheerful. the siller to see:
But I gied her something to carry,
A sure memorandum to be,
And syne she consentet to marry,
And wad hae nae ither but me.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: In a doop66 In a moment (Jamieson, Etymological Dictionary of the Scots Langauge). she began to grow wally,77 adj. plump, big, buxom strong; in this case, pregnant.
The neebours a’ fairli’t to see;
But I kent the reason fu’ brawly,88 Very well.
Wha soon was a daddy to be.
And when the black cutty99 n. horse or mare of two years of age. we mountet,
Her lads a’ leugh hearty at me;
But O how my courage was bluntet,
When fient a scrap siller had she.

head.title: Song II.1010 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 39-40, as part of Turnbull’s comedy The Recruit, first performed at the Dumfries Theater, January 1794 and sung by the character of the Serjeant, i.e. Mr. Shaw; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.head: I.
lg.l: My friends, unfeelingly, condemn

My passion for my Polly;1111 Name of the herione in John Gay's The Beggar's Opera (1728), first performed at Lincoln's Inn Theater in 1728 and frequently re-staged throughout the eighteenth century, and titular character in Gay's sequel, Polly (1729), first performed at the Haymarket Theatre in 1777.
They mock my sighs, and bid me leave
This am’rous melancholy.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The chearful glass, the jovial crew,
That were my pleasure wholly,
No more can ease this aching heart
That burns for thee, my Polly.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her!

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Forbear, unfeeling men, to rail,
Nor call my passion folly;
I’d sooner die, than cease to love
My dear, my charming Polly.
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
My tender flame discover!
Ah no, no, no, these sighs alone
Declare how much I love her !

head.title: Song IV.1212 First published in Poems (1794), p. 42, as part of Turnbull’s comedy The Recruit, first performed at the Dumfries Theater, January 1794 and sung by the character of the Drummer, i.e., Mr. O’Neil; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.head: I.
lg.l: The youth who is handsome, courageous and wise,
Will poverty, bardship, and labor despise;
The spade and the cart, the flail and teh plough,
He'll leave when he hears our row-de-dow-dow!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The lad who's in love, and his sweatheart unkind,
Let him cast all his cares at his back to the wind;
Nor to a coy mistress contentedly bow,
But leave her at once for our row-de-dow-dow!

lg.head: III.
lg.l: The man who is tied up in wedlock's close noose,
May quickly get rid of a termagant spouse;
Let her bellow and scold, the best he can do
Is, to leave her at once for our row-de-dow-dow!

head.title: Finale.1313 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 46-47, as part of Turnbull’s comedy The Recruit, first performed at the Dumfries Theater, January 1794 and sung by the characters of Sampson, i.e., Turnbull, the Drummer, i.e., Mr. O’Neil, Polly, i.e., Miss Harley, and the Serjeant, i.e., Mr. Shaw; subsequently reprinted with the songs from The Recruit in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (February 19, 1796).

lg.head: Sampson.
lg.l: Now, Nell, since we're ance mair agreed,
I'll to my mending soals wi' speed;
Mind you yer wheel--and as for you,
You've got the lad with the row, dow, dow!

lg.head: Drummer.
lg.l: Old boy, be wise and mind your trade,
And, Nell, let that curs'd tongue be laid,
Lest ye provoke him, when he's fou',
To follow the lads with the row-de-dow-dow!

lg.head: Polly.
lg.l: Then, farewel, mam, and farewel dad!
I'll march along with my soldier lad;
Love gives teh word, and our hearts beat true
With mutual joy, a row-de-dow-dow!

lg.head: Serjeant.
lg.l: In peace, or war, whate'er betide,
With such a sweet and charming bride
I'm bless'd for life--and chear'd by you,
I'll boldly march to the a row-de-dow-dow!
